questions.text: An 8-year-old girl is brought because of repetitive involuntary movements, including neck twisting, grimacing, grunting, and blinking, for the past 18 months. Her symptoms seem to improve with concentration and worsen with fatigue. Neurological examination shows multiple motor and vocal tics. Which is the most appropriate initial pharmacotherapy?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Risperidone This child presents with symptoms of Tourette syndrome , a condition characterized by involuntary vocal and motor tics . While mild, non-disabling symptoms are treated with behavioral therapy , pharmacotherapy is indicated if symptoms are severe or persist despite behavioral therapy. Since risperidone is effective in reducing the severity of tics and has few side effects, it is a common first-line medication .

questions.text: A 7-year-old child came with her mother because of failing to complete in-class assignments and homework and failing tests in reading, spelling, and arithmetic. He also reads slowly and inaccurately, often omits and adds few words in between sentences and has minimal comprehension, and has difficulties with spelling. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Dyslexia Reading impairment is characterized by difficulty in recognizing words , slow and inaccurate reading , poor comprehension , and difficulties with spelling. Characteristic diagnostic features include difficulty recalling , evoking, and sequencing printed letters and words; processing sophisticated grammatical constructions ; and making inferences.
